references.A95BAN01NAUS: Banks, R. C., and M. R. Browning. 1995. Comments on the status of revived old names for some North American birds. Auk 112:633-648.
references.B68BEN01NAUS: Bent, A. C. 1968. Life histories of North American cardinals, grosbeaks, buntings, towhees, finches, sparrows, and allies; order Passeriformes: family Fringillidae. Dover Publications, New York. Bull. U.S. Nat. Mus. 237.
references.B90KEL01SEGP: Keller, J. K. 1990. Using aerial photography to model species-habitat relationships: the importance of habitat size and shape. pp 34-46. in Mitchell, R. S., C. J. Sheviak, and D. J. Leopold eds. Ecosystem Mangement: Rare species and significant habitats. vol bull 471. New York, New York State Museum.
references.B83AOU01USGP: American Ornithologists' Union (AOU). 1983. Check-list of North American Birds, 6th edition. Allen Press, Inc., Lawrence, Kansas. 877 pp.
references.B79HAR01NAUS: Harrison, H.H. 1979. A field guide to western birds' nests. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston. 279 pp.
references.A91BYR01NAUS: Byrd, M.A., and D.W. Johnston. 1991. Birds. Pages 477-537 in K. Terwilliger, coordinator. Virginia's endangered species:proceedings of a symposium. McDonald and Woodward Publ. Co., Blacksburg, Virginia.
references.b06ALD01USGP: Alderfer, Jonathan. 2006. National Geographic Complete Birds of North America. National Geographic. Washington D.C. 696 pp.
references.B80TER01NAUS: Terres, J.K. 1980. The Audubon Society encyclopedia of North American birds. Alfred A. Knopf, New York.
references.B78HAR01NAUS: Harrison, C. 1978. A field guide to the nests, eggs and nestlings of North American birds. Collins, Cleveland, Ohio.

habitat_description:
Purple Finches (Carpodacus purpureus) primarily use moist and cool, open coniferous forest (especially fir and spruce) but are also frequently found in deciduous and mixed coniferous-deciduous forests, forest edges, open woodlands, second growth, orchards and other cultivated areas with trees, swamp openings, shrub bog edges, pastures and lawns with scattered conifers and shrubs, city parks, and suburbs (Wootten 1996, NatureServe 2009).  They can also be found foraging in chaparral, grasslands, or wet meadows.  Terres (1980) reported that they nest in conifers in the eastern U.S. and in both deciduous and conifer trees in the western U.S.  Alderfer (2006) described regional differences in habitat associations with eastern and northeastern birds inhabiting open coniferous forests and mixed woodlands and western birds inhabiting montane coniferous forests and oak canyons.  Keller (1990) found that they do not breed in old growth continuous deciduous forests in New York and they breed at higher densities at forest edges and in areas with denser understories.  In California, this species occurs in a variety of coastal foothills and lowlands and is found in mid-elevation mountain ranges during the breeding season where it builds nests in conifers and near water sources.  Forest edges are important in these regions (CA WHR, downloaded 07/09/2003; NatureServe 2004).  

Western breeders at high elevations migrate to lower elevations in the late summer or fall while eastern populations migrate to lower latitudes (Wootton 1996, Alderfer 2006).  In the winter, Purple Finches use a variety of habitats including coniferous, deciduous, and mixed coniferous-deciduous forests, urban and suburban areas, mixed shrub and conifer habitats, weedy fields, and hedgerows (Wootton 1996).

BISON (03/2002) reported an elevation range from 900 m to 2,130 m. 

N. Tarr, 22August2011.
